oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Toles Chapel CME: side view
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: West, Carroll Van, photographer
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Toles Chapel Christian Methodist Episcopal Church

Color photograph of church side. It is a modern, concrete-block building. Vestibule of the church contains wood siding. A single handrail enables access from the steps to the entranceway. Windows on the front of building appear to be painted over and no longer functional for lighting. A door appears in an addition to the right side of the vestibule. A set of concrete steps lead to the door. On the exterior side of the building's addition, a window remains with paint only partially obstructing the panes. The main building exhibits a cross-gabled roof design. The addition to the right features a gable and shed combination roof. A small, brick chimney juts from the ridge of the addition's roof.

Toles Chapel's first meetinghouse originally sat on the grounds presently occupied by the cemetery on Flatwoods Road. The land was purchased for six dollars in February 1907 by Oliver Toles, George Wyly, and Richard McAuley. The congregation eventually relocated to its current building, a former schoolhouse. Built as a Rosenwald-plan school between 1930 and 1940, Toles Chapel CME is a concrete-block building that sits in a well landscaped lot. Sometime after its construction, a small addition with a gable and shed roof, exterior door, and chimney was attached. The historic cemetery at the rear was a principal burial ground for local African Americans and reportedly contains hundreds of unmarked graves. The cemetery landscape has been altered by the movement and rearrangement of tombstones. At the time of fieldwork, Jerry Howard served as pastor and the property was considered eligible for the National Register.
